advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SCARY...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Can you believe it?! She is learning how to play flute (mini flute?) with her TO7... The father seems to be a kind of lunatic...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DESKTOP & PORTABLE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert on the Peerless 150 terminal</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The TO7 from Thomson has everything needed to fill the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special offer including italian books<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a part of a complete French price list of the C64 and VIC-20, including peripherals, accessories and software.<br> You can download the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Commodore/FrPriceList.zip">complete version</a>.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, the micro capital"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-502 was also called the Diabolik in France...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MONROE ADVERT, FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Intelligence is in the game"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gridcase made the cover of SVM (french magazine) in january 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>From the magazine 'Micro Sistemas' of March 1983 <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.mci.org.br </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This detailed advert presents a complete EXL-100 with all the pripherals available then (printer, disk, tape, modem, carts, etc.). <br><br> "Exelvision, the french micro-computing challenge"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 3.5'' Floppy disc drive + optional hard disk depending models
computer.description:
Please help us improve this description by sending us more info!
The PS/1 was IBM's return to the home computing market. It was the successor to the IBM PCjr, although it was compatible with IBM's bussines systems. The PS/1 was a propriatary system at first, but standard components were used later on. The later models included "Rapid Resume" a standby feature.
The system uses a LPX form factor (layout). Everything was built into the motherboard and had a four expansion slots of 16bit ISA but on a riser card. The memory was 72pin simms.
For the 486SX model for example, the CPU is integrated onto the motherboard but there is a socket3 that is empty. Apparently it is possible to put in another 486 CPU and the system disables the built-in CPU, which is not possible with the 386 model.
The software was Windows 3.1 and MS-DOS 6.2 on these systems. There is a bootloader from IBM that let you select ether to boot into DOS or Windows.
Contributors : Nick, Leland
computer.graphics: Original model: VGA modesLater models: sVGA modes
computer.keyboard: full stroke keyboard with numeric keypad and function keys
computer.media: 3.5'' Floppy disc drive + optional hard disk depending models
computer.name: PS/1
computer.peripherals: printer, expansion unit, hard drives, 5.25'' disk drive, etc.
computer.ram: Original model: 512 KB (max. 1 MB)Later models: from 1 MB to 64 MB
